44015016	" After these things I will return , And I will rebuild Davids fallen tent ; And I will build again its ruins , And I will set it up ;
44015017	" So that the rest of men may seek after the Lord , Even all the Gentiles , who are called by my name ,
44015018	" Says the Lord , who has been making this known from the beginning of the world .
44015019	" My judgment therefore , is against troubling those who turn to God from among the Gentiles ;
44015020	" but that we should write to them to abstain from the pollution of idols and from fornication , from meat killed by strangling , and from blood .
44015021	" For Moses from the earliest times has had his preachers in every town where he is read aloud , Sabbath after Sabbath , in the synagogues . "
44015022	Then it seemed good to the apostles and the elders , together with the whole church , to select some of their number , and to send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas . The men chosen were Judas called Bar-Sabbas , and Silas , leading men among the brethren .
44015023	They took with them the following letter . " The apostles and older brothers send greeting to the Gentile Brotherhood throughout Antioch and Syria and Cilicia ;
44015024	" as we have heard that some of your number who went out from us have troubled you with words and upset your souls , without having received any such instruction from us ;
44015025	" we have unanimously decided to select certain men , and to send them to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul ;
44015026	" men who have risked their very lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ .
44015027	" So we have sent Judas and Silas to tell you the same things by word of mouth .
44015028	" For it has seemed good to the Holy Ghost and to us , to lay upon you no greater burden than these necessary things ;
44015029	" that you abstain from food that has been sacrificed to idols , and from tasting blood , and from things strangled , and from fornication . Keep yourselves clear from these things and it will be well with you . Farewell . "
44015030	So they , when they had been despatched , went down to Antioch , and after gathering the whole multitude together , they handed them the letter ,
44015031	and when they had read it they rejoiced at the comfort it brought .
44015032	And Judas and Silas , who were themselves prophets , encouraged and strengthened the brothers with many a good counsel .
44015033	After spending some time there the brothers let them go with a greeting of peace to those who had sent them .
44015034	Silas , however , stayed with them .
44015035	Paul and Barnabas also stayed in Antioch teaching and proclaiming the word of the Lord , in company with others .
44015036	And after some days Paul said to Barnabas , " Let is go back and visit the brothers in every city in which we have proclaimed the word of the Lord . Let us see how they fare . "
44015037	Now Barnabas wanted to take with them John , who was called Mark .
44015038	But Paul thought it unwise to take with them one who had deserted them to the Pamphylia , and had not gone on with them to the work .
44015039	So there arose a sharp irritation , so that they parted company ; Barnabas taking Mark with him , sailed away to Cyprus ;
44015040	while Paul chose Silas , and set forth commended by the brothers to the grace of God .
44015041	He went through Syria and Cilicia , strengthening the churches .
44016001	And he came also to Derbe and Lystra , where there was a certain disciple named Timothy , the son of a believing Jewess , and of a Greek father .
44016002	He was well spoken of by the brothers in Lystra and Iconiun .
44016003	Now Paul , wishing that this man should accompany him on his journey , took him and circumcised him because of the local Jews , who all knew that his father was a Greek .
44016004	And as they went on their way through the cities they handed them the resolutions which the apostles and the elders in Jerusalem had ordained for them to keep .
44016005	So the churches were strengthened in the faith and continued to increase in number daily .
44016006	Then they went through Phrygia and Galatia , the Holy Spirit having forbidden them to proclaim the message in Asia .
44016007	When they got as far as Mysia , they attempted to enter Bithynia , but the Spirit of Jesus would not permit it ;
44016008	and so they passed by Mysia and went on down to Troas .
44016009	Here a vision appeared to Paul in the night . There stood a man of Macedonia , entreating him and saying , " Come over into Macedonia and help us ! "
44016010	So when he had seen the vision , we sought at once to go forth into Macedonia , because we concluded that God had called us to preach the gospel to them .
44016011	So we set sail from Troas and ran a straight course to Samothrace . The next day we arrived in Neapolis ,
44016012	and thence came to Philippi , a city of Macedonia , the fore most in its district , a Roman colony . There we stayed for some time .
44016013	On the Sabbath Day we went outside the city gate , to a riverside , where we supposed there was a place of prayer ; and we sat down and talked to the women who had gathered there .
44016014	Among them was a certain woman named Lydia , a seller of purple , who belonged to the town of Thyatira . She , since she was a worshiper of God , listened to us , and the Lord opened her heart to attend to what Paul said .
44016015	When she was baptized , and her household , she urged us , saying , " If in your judgment I am a believer in the Lord , come and stay at my house . " And she compelled us to come .
44016016	Now as we were going to the place of prayer , a certain slave girl met us , who had a spirit of divination , and who brought her masters great gain by fortune-telling .
44016017	She used to follow after Paul and us , crying out again and again , " These men are servants of the most high God , who proclaimed to you the way of salvation . "
44016018	She persisted in this for many days , until Paul , worn out , turned round and said to the spirit , " I charge you , in the name of Jesus Christ , to come out of her . " In that very hour it came out of her .
44016019	But when her owners saw that their hopes of gain were gone , they seized Paul and Silas , and dragged them before the magistrates , into the market-place .
44016020	Then they brought them before the praetors , saying . " These fellows are Jews , who are making a great disturbance in our city .
44016021	" They are teaching customs which it is not lawful for us as Romans to adopt or practise . "
44016022	The crowd , too , rose up together against them , and the praetors , after having them stripped , and after ordering them to be flogged ,
44016023	had many lashes inflicted upon them , and put them in prison , with a charge to the jailer to keep them safe .
44016024	On receiving so strict an order he cast them into the inner prison , and made their feet fast in the stocks .
44016025	But at midnight , while Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God , and the prisoners were listening to them ,
44016026	suddenly there was a great earthquake , so that the very foundations of the prison-house were shaken ; and instantly all the doors were opened , and every ones chains fell off .
44016027	The jailer , roused from sleep , and seeing the doors wide open , drew his sword and was about to kill himself , because he thought that the prisoners had escaped .
44016028	But Paul shouted loudly to him . " Do yourself no harm ; for we are all here ! "
44016029	So he called for lights , and sprang in , and , trembling for fear , fell down before Paul and Silas ,
44016030	and brought them out , saying , " Sirs , what must I do to be saved ? "
44016031	" Believe on the Lord Jesus , " they answered , " and you will be saved , you and all your household . "
44016032	Then they spoke the message of the Lord to him , as well as to all who were in his house .
44016033	And he took them , the same hour of the night , and washed their wounds , and he was baptized at once , he and all his .
44016034	And after bringing them up into his house , he set food before them , overjoyed with all his household in having believed in God .
44016035	But in the morning the praetors sent their lictors with the order , " Let these men go . "
44016036	The jailer reported the words to Paul , saying . " The praetors have sent to release you ; so come out , and go in peace . "
44016037	But Paul said . " They have flogged us publicly , uncondemned , men that are Roman citizens ; and have thrown us into prison . Are they now going to get rid of us secretly ? No , indeed ! Let them come here , themselves and take us out . "
44016038	The lictors reported these words to the praetors , who were frightened when they heard that they were Romans .
44016039	So they came and conciliated them , and after taking them out of prison , begged them to leave the town .
44016040	So Paul and Silas came out of the prison , and went to Lydias house ; and after they had seen the brethren and encouraged them , they left Philippi .
44017001	Now when they had gone through Amphipolis and Apollonia , they came to Thessalonica . Here there was a Jewish synagogue ,
44017002	and Paul , according to his usual custom , went in to them and , for three Sabbath Days , he reasoned with them out of the Scriptures ,
44017003	explaining and quoting passages to prove that the Messiah had to suffer and to rise again from the dead and that " This Jesus whom I am proclaiming unto you is the Messiah . "
44017004	Some were persuaded and attached themselves to Paul and Silas , including a number of devout Greeks , and a large number of the leading women .
44017005	But the Jews , moved with jealousy , called to their aid certain ill-favored and idle fellows , formed a mob , and began to set the town in an uproar . Assaulting the house of Jason , they sought to bring them out to the people .
44017006	And when they had failed to find Paul and Silas , they began to drag Jason and some of the brethren before the politarchs , shouting . " These fellows who have upset the habitable earth are come hither also .
44017007	" Jason has received them , and they all act contrary to the decrees of Caesar , saying that there is another king , one Jesus . "
44017008	Both the crowd and the politarchs were disturbed when they heard this ,
44017009	but when they had taken security from Jason and the rest , they let them go .
44017010	Now the brothers sent Paul and Silas away by night to Berea . When they got there they betook themselves to the Jewish synagogue .
44017011	The Jews of Berea were more noble than those in Thessalonica , in that they very readily received the message with all readiness of mind , and day after day searched the Scriptures to see whether these things were so .
44017012	So many of them became believers , and so did not a few Greeks , women of honorable estate , and men .
44017013	As soon as the Jews in Thessalonica learned that the word of God was preached by Paul in Berea also , they came there , and stirred up and troubled the crowds .
44017014	Then the brothers at once sent Paul down to the sea , but Silas and Timothy remained behind .
44017015	Those who were caring for Paul brought him as far as Athens , and there left him , with instructions to Silas and Timothy to come to him with all speed .
44017016	While Paul was waiting for them at Athens , his spirit was stirred within him , when he noticed that the city was full of idols .
44017017	He argued in the synagogues with the Jews and the devout proselytes , and also daily in the market-place with those that met him there .
44017018	A few of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also encountered him again and again . Some were saying , " What has this beggarly fellow to say ? " Others said , " He seems to be a setter forth of strange gods , " because he preached Jesus and the resurrection .
44017019	Then they laid hold of him and brought him up to Mars Hill , saying . " May we be told what this new teaching of yours is ?
44017020	" For you are bringing certain strange things to our ears . We want to know , therefore , what these things mean . "
44017021	( Now all the Athenians and the strangers sojourning there spent their time in nothing else , but to tell or to hear some new thing . )
44017022	So Paul stood up in the center of Mars Hill , and said . " Men of Athens , I perceive that in all respects you are remarkably religious .
44017023	" For as I was passing along and observing your objects of worship , I found also an altar with this inscription , TO AN UNKNOWN GOD . What you are worshiping in ignorance , this I am proclaiming to you .
44017024	" The God who made the universe and all things in it , he , being Lord of heaven and earth , does not dwell in temples made with hands ,
44017025	" neither is he served by mens hands , as though he needed anything , since he himself gives to all life and breath and all things .
44017026	" He has made of one blood every nation of men to dwell on all the face of the earth , having determined their appointed seasons and the bounds of their habitation ,
44017027	" so that they might seek God , if perhaps they might feel after him and find him , though he is not far from every on of us ;
44017028	" for in him we live and move and have our being ; as certain even of your own poets have said , " For we also are his offspring .
44017029	" Since then we are Gods offspring , we ought not to imagine that the Godhead is like to gold , or silver , or stone , graven by art and device of man .
44017030	" The times of ignorance God overlooked , but he now commands all men that they should all , everywhere , repent ;
44017031	inasmuch as he has fixed a day in which he will judge the world justly , by the Man whom he has ordained , and he has given proof of all this by raising him from the dead . "
44017032	But on hearing of the resurrection of the dead , some began to mock ; but others said , " We will hear you again on that subject . "
44017033	So Paul withdrew from them .
44017034	A few , however , attached themselves to him and believed , among whom was Dionysius the Areopagite , and a woman named Damaris , and some others .
44018001	After this Paul left Athens and went to Corinth .
44018002	Here he found a certain Jew named Aquila , a native of Pontus , who had recently come from Italy with his wife , Priscilla , because Claudius had ordered all Jews to leave Rome .
44018003	Paul came to them , and because he was of the same trade with them , he lodged with them , and worked with them - for by trade they were tentmakers .
44018004	Every Sabbath he used to preach in the synagogue , and tried to persuade both Jews and Greeks .
44018005	And when Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia , Paul was engrossed in his message , earnestly testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Messiah .
44018006	But as they opposed him and abused him , he shook out his garments in protest , and said . " Your blood be upon your own hands . I am clean . From now on I will go to the Gentiles . "
44018007	So he left the place , and went into the house of a man named Titus Justus , a worshiper of God , whose house adjoined the synagogue .
44018008	And Crispus , the warden of the synagogue , believed on the Lord , with all his household ; and many of the Corinthians from time to time listened , believed , and were baptized .
44018009	And the Lord said to Paul in a vision , by night . " Have no fear ; go on speaking , and do not keep silent ;
44018010	" for I am with you , and no one shall set upon you to injure you ; for I have very many people in this city . "
44018011	So he lived there a year and six months and continued to teach them the word of God .
44018012	But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia , the Jews with one accord rose against Paul , and brought him before the tribunal .
44018013	" This fellow , " they said , " is persuading men to offer unlawful worship to God . "
44018014	Paul was about to open his mouth , when Gallio said to the Jews . " If it had been some misdemeanor or wicked villainy , it would have been within reason for me to listen to you Jews ;
44018015	but as these are merely questions about words and names and your own law , you yourselves must see to it . I am not willing to be a judge of these matters . "
44018016	And he drove them from the tribunal .
44018017	Then they all laid hold of Sosthenes , the warden of the synagogue , and beat him in front of the tribunal ; but Gallio took no notice .
44018018	And Paul after remaining in Corinth some time longer , took leave of the brothers , and sailed away to Syria , accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila . As Paul was under a vow , he had his head shaved at Cenchrea .
44018019	When they came to Ephesus he left them there ; but he himself entered into the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews .
44018020	When they begged him to stay longer , he would not consent ,
44018021	but said , as he took leave of them , " I will return again to you , if God will . "
44018022	Then , setting sail from Ephesus , he landed at Caesarea ; he went up to Jerusalem and saluted the church , and came down to Antioch .
44018023	After spending some time there , he set out and went through the region of Galatia and Phrygia , in order , and strengthened all the disciples .
44018024	Now a certain Jew named Apollos , a native of Alexandria , a learned man and mighty in the Scriptures , came to Ephesus .
44018025	He had been instructed in the ways of the Lord , and being full of zeal , he used to speak and to teach accurately the facts about Jesus , although he knew only the baptism of John .
44018026	He began to speak boldly in the synagogue ; and when Priscilla and Aquila heard him they took him home and explained to him more accurately the way of God .
44018027	When he wished to cross over into Achaia , the brothers encouraged him , and wrote to the disciples in Corinth to receive him . On his arrival he mightily helped those who through grace had believed ,
44018028	for he powerfully refuted the Jews in public argument , proving to them from the Scriptures that Jesus is the Messiah .
44019001	Now it happened that while Apollos was in Corinth , Paul , after passing through the hinterland , came to Ephesus , where he found a few disciples .
44019002	" Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed ? " he asked them . " No " said they , " we did not even hear that there is a Holy Spirit . "
44019003	" Into what , then , were you baptized ? " he asked . And they said , " Into the baptism of John . "
44019004	" John indeed baptized with the baptism of repentance , " answered Paul , " telling the people to believe on One who was coming after him , namely , on Jesus . "
44019005	When they heard this they were baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus ;
44019006	and after Paul had laid his hands on them , the Holy Spirit came upon them , and they began to speak with tongues , and to prophesy .
44019007	They were in all about twelve men .
44019008	Then Paul went into the synagogue , and there continued to preach fearlessly for about three months , reasoning and persuading them about the kingdom of God .
44019009	But when some grew hardened and disobedient , and spoke evil of the Way before the crowd , he left them , withdrew the disciples , and continued to hold discussions daily in the lecture-hall of Tyrannus .
44019010	This went on for two years , so that all the inhabitants of Asia heard the Lords message , Jews as well as Greeks .
44019011	God also wrought extraordinary miracles by the hand of Paul ;
44019012	so much so , that handkerchiefs or aprons were carried away from his body to the sick ; and their diseases departed from them , and the evil spirits went out .
44019013	But there were also some strolling Jewish exorcists , who took it upon them to invoke the name of Jesus over those who had evil spirits , saying , " I adjure you by that Jesus whom Paul preaches . "
44019014	There were seven sons of one Sceva , a Jewish high priest who used to do this .
44019015	But the evil spirit answered , " Jesus I know , and Paul I have heard of , but who are you ? "
44019016	And the man in whom the evil spirit was sprang on two of them , overpowered them and prevailed against them , so that they fled out of the house naked and wounded .
44019017	And this became known to all the people of Ephesus , both Jews and Greeks . Awe fell on them all , and the name of the Lord Jesus began to be held in honor .
44019018	Many also of those who became believers used to come to confess and to declare their deeds .
44019019	And some of them who had practised magic arts , collected their books , and burned them in the presence of all . And they counted the price of them , and found it to be fifty thousand silver coins .
44019020	So mightily the word of the Lord continued to grow and to prevail .
44019021	Now after these things were ended , Paul resolved in his spirit to travel through Macedonia and Achaia on his way to Jerusalem . " After I get there , " he said , " I must see Rome , too . "
44019022	So he sent two of his assistants , Timothy and Erastus , into Macedonia , while he himself kept back for a time on his way into Asia .
44019023	Now just at this time , there arose no small commotion concerning the Way .
44019024	There was a man named Demetrius , a silversmith , who made silver shrines of Diana , and brought rich profit to his workmen .
44019025	He gathered them together with others of like occupation , and said . " Men , you know that by this business we make our money .
44019026	" And you see and hear that not only in Ephesus , but almost throughout all of Asia , this fellow Paul has persuaded and turned away many people , by telling them that they are no gods at all who are made with hands .
44019027	" So there is danger not only that our trade come into disrepute , but also that the temple of the great goddess Diana will be brought into disrepute , and that she herself may even be deposed from her magnificence , she whom all Asia and the world now worships . "
44019028	After listening to this they were filled with rage , and cried out again and again , saying ,
44019029	The city was filled with commotion . They rushed like one man into the theater , dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus , Macedonians , Pauls companions in travel .
44019030	When Paul wanted to go in to the people , the disciples would not let him ,
44019031	and some of the Asiarchs , too , who were his friends , sent word to him repeatedly , entreating him not to venture into the theater .
44019032	Now some were shouting one thing , some another , for the assembly was in an uproar , and the majority had no idea why they were come together .
44019033	And they brought Alexander out of the crowd , whom the Jews had pushed forward . And Alexander , motioning with his hand , would have made a defense to the people ,
44019034	but when they saw that he was a Jew they all , with one voice , for about two hours , shouted ,
44019035	At length the recorder got them quiet . " Men of Ephesus , " he said , " who here does not know that the city of the Ephesians is temple-guardian of the great Diana and of the image which fell down from Jupiter ?
44019036	" Since these facts cannot be gainsaid , you ought to be calm and do nothing reckless .
44019037	" For you have brought these men here , who are neither robbers of temples nor blasphemers of our goddess .
44019038	If then Demetrius and his craftsmen have a grievance against any one , the courts are open and there are the proconsuls ; let them accuse one another .
44019039	But if you desire anything further , it must be settled in the regular assembly .
44019040	For indeed we are in danger of being accused in regard to this days riot , since there is no cause for it , nor shall we be able to give account for this disorderly gathering . "
44019041	With these words he dismissed the assembly .
44020001	After the uproar had ceased , Paul sent for the disciples and , after embracing them , bade them farewell , and started for Macedonia .
44020002	And when he had passed through those districts and encouraged the disciples in many addresses , he came into Greece where he spent three months .
44020003	Just as he was about to set sail for Syria , the Jews laid a plot against him , and he determined to return through Macedonia .
44020004	There accompanied him as far as Asia , Sopater of Berea , the son of Pyrrhus ; and of the Thessalonians , Aristarchus and Secundus ; and Gaius of Derbe , and Timothy ; and the Asians , Tychicus and Trophimus .
44020005	Now these had gone on , and were awaiting us at Troas ;
44020006	but we ourselves set sail from Philippi , after the days of unleavened bread , and joined them five days later at Troas . There we remained for a week .
44020007	On the first day of the week we met for the breaking of bread , and Paul , who was going away the next morning , began preaching to them , and prolonged his discourse until midnight .
44020008	Now there were many lamps in the upper room where we were assembled ,
44020009	and a young man named Eutychus was sitting in a window , overborne by deep sleep , while Paul continued to preach at length . Overcome at last by sleep , he fell down from the third story , and was taken up dead .
44020010	Then Paul went down , threw himself upon him , and embracing him , said . " Do not lament ; his life is still in him . "
44020011	Then he went upstairs again , broke bread and took some food , and after talking with them a long time , even until daybreak , he left them .
44020012	They had taken the lad home alive , and were not a little comforted .
44020013	The rest of us going before to the ship , set sail for Assos , intending to take Paul on board there ; for so he had appointed , because he intended to go by land .
44020014	And when he met us at Assos , we took him in , and came to Mitylene .
44020015	We sailed from thence , and arrived next day off Chios ; and the day after we touched at Samos ; and the following day we came to Mitylene .
44020016	For Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus , so as not to spend time in Asia , for he was hurrying to get to Jerusalem , if it were possible , by the day of Pentecost .
44020017	From Miletus he sent to Ephesus for the elders of the church to come to him ;
44020018	and when they arrived , he said to them . " You yourselves know quite well , how I lived among you , from the first day that I set foot in Asia ,
44020019	" serving the Lord with all lowliness of mind , and with tears , and amid trials that befell me through the plots of the Jews .
44020020	" You know that I never shrank from declaring to you anything that was profitable , nor from teaching you publicity and in your homes ,
44020021	testifying both to Jews and Greeks repentance toward God , and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ .
44020022	And now I am going to Jerusalem , bound in the Spirit , not knowing what will befall me there ,
44020023	except that in city after city the Holy Spirit is warning me that bonds and afflictions are awaiting me .
44020024	But I hold not my life of any account , as dear unto myself , if only I may run my race , and accomplish the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus , to attest the gospel of the grace of God .
44020025	And now I know that not one of you among whom I went about preaching the kingdom , will ever see my face again .
44020026	So I testify to you this day that I am clear from the blood of all men ;
44020027	I never shrank from telling you the whole counsel of God .
44020028	Take heed to yourselves and to all the flock of which the Holy Spirit has appointed you overseers , and be shepherds of the church of God which he has purchased with his own blood .
44020029	I know that after my departure fierce wolves will come among you , and they will not spare the flock ;
44020030	and that from among your own number , men will arise , perverting the truth , to draw away the disciples after them .
44020031	So be on guard ; and remember that for three years I ceased not to admonish you all , night and day , even with tears .
44020032	" And now I commend you to God and to the word of his grace . He is able to build you up , and to give you your inheritance among all those who are consecrated .
44020033	" No mans silver or gold of clothing did I ever covet .
44020034	" You yourselves know how these hands of mine provided for my needs , and those of my companions .
44020035	" In all things I have set you an example , how that so toiling , you ought to help the weak and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus , how he himself said , " It is more blessed to give than to receive . "
44020036	When he had so said , Paul kneeled down , and prayed with them .
44020037	And they all began , with loud lamentations , to throw their arms about his neck , and to kiss him lovingly , again and again ,
44020038	sorrowing most of all for the words that he had spoken , that after that day they should look upon his face no more . And they began to escort him to the ship .
44021001	When at least we had torn ourselves away , and had set sail , we ran a straight course to Cos , and next day to Rhodes , and from there to Patara .
44021002	And when we had found a ship bound for Phoenicia , we went aboard and set sail .
44021003	After sighting Cyprus and leaving it on the left hand , we sailed for Syria , and put in at Tyre ; for there the ship was to unload her cargo .
44021004	We looked up the local disciples and remained there seven days ; and these disciples kept telling Paul , through the Spirit , that he should not set foot in Jerusalem .
44021005	When , however , our time was up , we left and started on our journey ; and all of them , with wives and children , were escorting us on our way until we were out of the city ; then , kneeling down on the beach , we prayed ,
44021006	and said good-bye , and went on board the ship , while they returned home again .
44021007	And when we had finished the voyage from Tyre , we reached Ptolemais , and greeted the brothers and stayed with them one day .
44021008	On the morrow we started for Caesarea , where we went into the house of Philip , the evangelist , who was one of the seven , and stayed with him .
44021009	Now Philip had four unmarried daughters who prophesied ,
44021010	and while we remained there many days , a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea .
44021011	He came to us , and taking Pauls girdle , he bound his own feet and hands , saying , " Thus says the Holy Spirit , so will the Jews at Jerusalem bind the owner of this girdle , and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles . "
44021012	As soon as we heard these words , both we and those who were standing near entreated Paul not to go up to Jerusalem .
44021013	" What do you mean by thus breaking my heart with your grief ? " answered Paul . " For I am ready not to be bound only , but also to die at Jerusalem , for the name of the Lord Jesus . "
44021014	And when he would not be persuaded , we ceased , saying , " The will of the Lord be done . "
44021015	A few days after this we took up our luggage and went up to Jerusalem .
44021016	And some of the disciples from Caesarea accompanied us . They led us to the house of Mnason , a Cypriote , a disciple of long standing , with whom we were to lodge .
44021017	At length we reached Jerusalem , and the brothers there received us gladly .
44021018	On the following day we went with Paul to call on James , and all the elders were present .
44021019	After saluting them Paul rehearsed , one by one , the things that God had done among the Gentiles by his ministry .
44021020	And they , when they heard it , glorified God , and said to him . " You see , brother , how many thousands there are among the Jews , of those who have believed , and they are all zealous for the Law .
44021021	" Now what they have been told about you , again and again , is that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles , to forsake Moses , and not to circumcise their children , nor to follow the old customs .
44021022	" What then ought to be done ? They will certainly hear that you are come .
44021023	" So do this that we tell you .
44021024	" We have four men here under a vow ; associate yourself with them , purify yourself with them , and pay their expenses so that they may have their heads shaved ; then every one will know that there is no truth in the rumors that they have heard about you ; but that you yourself walk orderly obeying the law .
44021025	" As for the Gentile believers , we wrote giving judgment that they should abstain from anything sacrificed to an idol , from blood , from what is strangled , and from fornication . "
44021026	Then Paul took the men , and after purifying himself with them next day , went into the temple to declare the fulfilment of the days of purification , until the offering was offered for every one of them .
44021027	But when the seven days were almost over , the Asiatic Jews caught sight of him in the temple , and began to stir up all the crowd , and laid hands on him , shouting .
44021028	" Men of Israel , help ! This is the man who goes everywhere preaching to everybody against the people , and the Law , and this place . And he has actually brought Gentiles even into the temple , and has desecrated the holy place . "
44021029	( For they had formerly seen Trophimus , the Ephesian , with him in the city , and supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple . )
44021030	The whole city was thrown into uproar . The mob surged together , seized Paul , and began to drag him outside the temple . Whereupon the doors were at once shut .
44021031	While they were attempting to kill him , news came to the tribune commander of the garrison that all Jerusalem was in an uproar .
44021032	At once he took soldiers and centurions , and rushed down upon them . When they saw the tribune and the troops , they left off beating Paul .
44021033	Then the tribune came up and seized him , and ordered that he be bound with two chains . " Who is he ? " he began asking , " and what has he done ? "
44021034	Some among the crowd kept shouting one thing , some another ; and when the tribune could not learn the facts because of the uproar , he ordered Paul into the barracks .
44021035	When was going up the steps , he had to be carried by the soldiers , because of the violence of the mob ,
44021036	for the whole mass of the people were following him , shouting , " Away with him ! "
44021037	Just as he was about to be taken into the barracks , Paul said to the tribune , " May I speak to you ? "
44021038	" Do you know Greek ? " said the tribune ; " Are you not , then , the Egyptian who in days gone by stirred up to sedition , and let into the wilderness the four thousand cutthroats ? "
44021039	" I am a Jew , " answered Paul , " a native of Tarsus in Cilicia , a citizen of no mean city . And I pray you , give me permission to speak to the people . "
44021040	So when he had given leave , Paul stood on the stairs , beckoning with his hands to the people . There came a great hush , and he spoke to them as follows , in Hebrew .
44022001	" Brothers and fathers , listen to the defense which I now make in your presence . "
44022002	When they heard him speaking in Hebrew they became the more quiet .
44022003	" I am a Jew , " he said , " born in Tarsus of Cilicia , but brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel , taught according to the strict manner of the Law of our forefathers , ardent for God , even as you all are this day .
44022004	" I persecuted to the death this way , continually binding and delivering up to prisons both men and women .
44022005	" To this the high priest and all the council of elders are witnesses . It was from them that I received letters to the brothers in Damascus , and I was already on my way to bring those also who were there back to Jerusalem , in bonds , for punishment .
44022006	" But when , on my journey , I was nearing Damascus , about noon , suddenly a great light from heaven shone round about me .
44022007	" I fell to the ground , and heard a voice saying to me , " Saul ! Saul ! why are you persecuting me ?
44022008	" Who are you , Lord ? I asked . " I am Jesus , the Nazarene , whom you are persecuting , he answered me .
44022009	" Now my companions , though they beheld the light , did not hear the words of Him who spoke to me .
44022010	" And I said , What shall I do , Lord ? and the Lord said to me , Rise and go into Damascus , and there you will be told about all that you are destined to do .
44022011	" And as I was seeing nothing for the glory of the light , I was led by the hand of my companions , and so came into Damascus .
44022012	" And a certain Ananias , a pious man according to the Law , well thought of by all the Jews who lived there ,
44022013	" came to me , and standing by me , said to me , " Brother Saul , receive your sight " In that very hour I regained my sight and looked up at him .
44022014	" Then he said . " The God of our forefathers has appointed you to know his will ; and to see the righteous One , and to hear a voice from his mouth .
44022015	" For before the face of all men you will be a witness for him of what you have seen and heard .
44022016	" And now why do you wait ? Rise and be baptized , and wash away your sins , calling upon his name .
44022017	" After my return to Jerusalem , and while I was praying in the temple ,
44022018	" I fell into a trance and saw him saying to me , " Make haste and go quickly out of Jerusalem , because they will not receive your testimony concerning me .
44022019	" Lord , I replied , they themselves well know that I was beating and imprisoning in synagogue after synagogue those who believed in you ,
44022020	" and when the blood of your martyr Stephen was shed , I also was standing by and consenting , and holding the garments of his murders .
44022021	" Depart , he said to me , for I will send you forth , far hence , to the Gentiles . "
44022022	Until they heard this last statement , the people were listening to Paul , but now they roared out . " Away with such a fellow from the earth ! He is not fit to live ! "
44022023	When they continued to shout , throwing their clothes into the air , and flinging dust around ,
44022024	the tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks , and examined under the lash , to learn for what reason the people were thus crying out against him .
44022025	But when they had tied him up with the thongs , Paul said to the centurion who was standing near , " If a man is a Roman citizen , and uncondemned , is it lawful for you to scourge him ? "
44022026	When the centurion heard that , he went to the tribune and said to him . " What are you intending to do ? This man is a Roman citizen . "
44022027	So the tribune came to Paul and asked him , " Tell me , are you a Roman citizen ? " " Yes , " he said .
44022028	" I paid a large sum to get this citizenship , " said the tribune . " But I was citizen-born , " said Paul .
44022029	Then those who were about to scourge him , immediately left him . And the tribune too , was afraid , when he learned that Paul was a Roman citizen , for he had had him bound .
44022030	The next day , as he wished to learn the real reason why the Jews accused Paul , he unbound him , and commanded the chief priests and all the Sanhedrin to come together , and brought Paul down , and placed him before them .
44023001	With a stedfast gaze at the Sanhedrin , Paul said , " Brothers , I have lived with a good conscience before God to this day . "
44023002	Then the High Priest Ananias ordered those who stood near Paul to strike him on the mouth .
44023003	" You whited sepulcher , " exclaimed Paul , " God will strike you ! You are sitting there to judge me according to the law , are you ? And do you command me to be struck , contrary to the Law ? "
44023004	" Do you rail at Gods high priest ? " said the bystanders .
44023005	" Brothers , I did not know that he was the high priest , " exclaimed Paul , " for it is written , Thou shalt not speak evil of a ruler of my people . "
44023006	Then perceiving that half the Sanhedrin were Sadducees and the other half Pharisee , he cried out in the Sanhedrin . " Brothers , I am a Pharisee , the son of Pharisees ! It is for the hope of the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial ! "
44023007	When he said this , there arose a quarrel between the Pharisees and Sadducees ; the meeting was divided .
44023008	For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection , neither angel nor spirit ; the Pharisees affirm them all .
44023009	Then a great clamor arose ; some of the scribes who belonged to the Pharisaic party stood up , and contended . " We find nothing wrong in this man . What if a spirit has spoken to him , or an angel ? "
44023010	But when the dissension became violent , the tribune , fearing that they would tear Paul in pieces , ordered the troops to march down and take him by force from among them , and bring him into the barracks .
44023011	And the following night the Lord stood by him and said . " Be of good courage ; for as you have borne faithful witness concerning me at Jerusalem , so you must testify at Rome also . "
44023012	When day dawned the Jews made a conspiracy , and bound themselves under a curse , saying that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul .
44023013	And there were more than forty who had sworn this oath .
44023014	They went to the high priests and elders , and said to them . " We have bound ourselves by a solemn oath to eat nothing until we have killed Paul .
44023015	" Now do you and the Sanhedrin ask the tribune to bring him down to you , as though you would judge his case more exactly ; and we are ready to kill him , before he comes near the place . "
44023016	But Pauls sisters son heard of their intended attack , and he went and got into the barracks , and told Paul .
44023017	And Paul called one of the centurions , and said , " Take this young man to the tribune , for he has something to tell him . "
44023018	So he took him , and brought his to the tribune , and said , " Paul , the prisoner , called me to him , and begged me to bring this young man to you , because he has something to tell you . "
44023019	And the tribune took him by the hand , and going aside , asked him privately , " What is it that you have to tell me ? "
44023020	" The Jews , " he answered , " have agreed to ask you to bring down Paul tomorrow to the Sanhedrin , as though they wish to examine his case in detail .
44023021	" Now do not let them persuade , for more than forty men are lying in wait for him , who have bound themselves under a curse , not to eat nor drink until they have killed him ; even now they are all ready , awaiting your consent . "
44023022	So the tribune sent the young man home with the injunction , " Tell no man that you have given me this information . "
44023023	Then he called two centurions to him and said . " Get ready by nine oclock tonight two hundred infantry to march as far as Caesarea , and also seventy troopers and two hundred spearmen . "
44023024	He further ordered them to provide horses on which to mount Paul , so as to bring him safely to Felix , the governor .
44023025	He also wrote a letter in the following terms .
44023026	" Claudius Lysais unto the Most Excellent Governor Felix , greeting .
44023027	" This man Paul had been seized by the Jews , and was about to be killed by them , when I came upon them with the troops , and rescued him , as I had learned that he was a Roman citizen .
44023028	" Anxious to find out why they had accused him , I brought him down to their Sanhedrin .
44023029	" Here I learned that he was accused about questions of their law , but was not charged with anything worthy of death or imprisonment .
44023030	" Now when I received information that there would be a plot against the man , I sent him at once to you , charging his accusers also to speak against him before you . "
44023031	So the soldiers took Paul , as they were bid , and brought him by night to Antipatris .
44023032	Next day the infantry returned to the barracks , leaving the troopers to ride on with him .
44023033	They reached Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor , and also presented Paul before him .
44023034	After reading the letter , he asked to what province he belonged , and when he understood that he was of Cilicia , he said ,
44023035	" I will hear your case when your accusers also are come . " And he ordered him to be kept in custody in Herods palace .
44024001	Five days later , Ananias the high priest came down to Caesarea with some of the elders , and with an orator , named Tertullus . They laid information before the governor against Paul .
44024002	So Paul was sent for , and then Tertullus began to accuse him , saying . " As it is owing to your excellency that we enjoy profound peace , and that the state of this nation ,
44024003	" owing to your wise care , has been improved in every respect and in every place , we accept it with profound thankfulness .
44024004	" But not to weary you too much , I beg of your Excellency to listen to a few words from us .
44024005	" For we have found this fellow a pest , an inciter of insurrection among all the Jews of the empire , and a ringleader in the heresy of the Nazarenes .
44024006	" He even tried to profane the Temple , but we arrested him .
44024007	" Then the chief captain , Lysias came and violently took him from us .
44024008	From him you will be able , by examining Paul yourself , to learn the truth of all these charges we are bringing against him . "
44024009	The Jews also joined in the charge , maintaining that these were the facts .
44024010	Then at a nod from the governor , Paul spoke . " Because I know that for many years you have been a judge in this nation , I feel encouraged to make my defense .
44024011	" For you have it in your power to know that it is not more than twelve days ago that I went up to Jerusalem to worship ;
44024012	" and that neither in the Temple , nor in the synagogues , nor in the city , did they find me disputing with any man or stirring up a crowd .
44024013	" Nor can they prove the charges which they are now bringing against me .
44024014	" But this I confess to you , that I worship the God of our ancestors , according to the Way which they call a heresy , believing everything that is according to the Law , or is written in the Prophets ,
44024015	" and having hope toward God , which these also themselves look for , that there is to be a resurrection both of the just and the unjust .
44024016	" Hence I too endeavor to have a conscience void of offense toward God and men alway .
44024017	" Now after many years I came to bring alms to my nation , and to offer sacrifices .
44024018	" While I was thus engaged , they found me in the temple , purified , with no crowd and no uproar . But there were certain Asiatic Jews
44024019	" who ought to have been here before you , and to have made accusations if they had anything against me .
44024020	" Or let these men themselves say what fault they found , when I appeared before the Sanhedrin !
44024021	" Unless it was for this one sentence which I uttered when I stood and cried , It is for the resurrection of the dead that I am on my trial today before you . "
44024022	At this point Felix , who had a pretty accurate knowledge of the Way , adjourned the case , saying to the Jews , " When Lysias the tribune comes down , I will go carefully into the matter . "
44024023	And he gave orders to the centurion that Paul should be kept in custody , but treated with indulgence , and that his personal friends were not to be forbidden to minister to him .
44024024	Some days later Felix came , with his wife Drusilla , a Jewess ; he sent for Paul , and listened to him concerning the faith in Christ Jesus .
44024025	And as he reasoned about morality , self-control , and the future judgment , Felix was terrified , and said , " For the present go on your way , and when I find a convenient season , I will send for you . "
44024026	He was hoping that Paul would give him money , and for this reason he used to send for him often to converse with him .
44024027	But after two full years Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus , and because he wished to curry favor with the Jews , Felix left Paul still in prison .
44025001	Three days after Festus entered his province , he went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem .
44025002	The high priest and the Jewish leaders laid charges against Paul before him .
44025003	They urged him , asking it as a favor , to send for him to Jerusalem . They meant to lay in wait for him and kill him on the way .
44025004	But Festus answered that Paul was in custody at Caesarea , and that he himself was going there soon .
44025005	" Let those then , " he said , " who are in authority among you , go down with me , and if there is anything amiss in the man , let them accuse him . "
44025006	After staying not more than eight or ten days among them , he went down to Caesarea , and the next day , after taking his seat upon the tribunal , he ordered Paul to be brought .
44025007	When he came in , the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him and brought a number of serious charges against him , which they could not prove .
44025008	Paul said in his defense , " I have committed no crime against the Law of the Jews , against the Temple , or against Caesar . "
44025009	But Festus , wishing to ingratiate himself with the Jews , answered Paul and said , " Will you go up to Jerusalem and be tried there by me upon these charges ? "
44025010	" I am standing before Caesars tribunal , " answered Paul , " where I ought to be tried . I have done no wrong to the Jews , as you very well know .
44025011	" If I am a criminal and have done anything for which I ought to die , I do not object to die . But if none of their charges is true , no man can give me up to them . I appeal to Caesar . "
44025012	Then Festus , after conferring with the council , answered . " You have appealed to Caesar ; to Caesar you shall go . "
44025013	A short time after this King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to pay their respects to Festus .
44025014	And while they tarried many days , Festus laid Pauls case before the king . " There is a man here , " he said , " whom Felix left a prisoner .
44025015	" The chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me about him , when I was at Jerusalem , demanding a sentence against him .
44025016	I told them that it was not the custom of the Romans to give any man up for punishment , before the accused had his accusers face to face , and had opportunity of defending himself against the charges that had been brought against him .
44025017	" So when a number of them came together here , I made no delay , but the next day took my seat in the tribunal , and commanded the man to be brought .
44025018	" But when his accusers stood up , they did not begin charging him with any of the crimes that I was expecting ,
44025019	but they kept quarreling with him about certain matters connected with their own religion , and about one Jesus who had died , but whom Paul affirmed over and over was alive .
44025020	I was perplexed how to investigate such questions , and asked Paul whether he would go to Jerusalem , and there be judged of these matters .
44025021	But when Paul appealed to have his case reviewed for the decision of the Emperor , I ordered him to be detained until I could send him up to Caesar . "
44025022	" I should like to hear the man , myself , " said Agrippa to Festus . Festus answered , " You shall hear him tomorrow . "
44025023	So the next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp , and took their places in the hall of audience , accompanied by the tribunes and men of high rank in the city . At the command of Festus Paul was brought in .
44025024	" King Agrippa , " said Festus , " and all men who are present with us , you see here the man about whom the entire body of the Jews at Jerusalem , and here also , sent to me , crying out that he ought not to live any longer .
44025025	" I could not find that he had done anything for which he ought to die ; but as he himself has appealed to the Emperor , I have determined to send him .
44025026	" Now I have nothing very definite to tell our sovereign about him . So I have brought the man before you all , and especially before you , King Agrippa , in order that , after examination , I may have something to write .
44025027	" For it does seem to me unreasonable to send a person without signifying the charges against him . "
44026001	Then Agrippa said to Paul , " You are permitted to speak for yourself . " So Paul stretched forth his hand and began to make his defense .
44026002	" I think myself happy , King Agrippa , that I am to make my defense before you this day , in regard to all the accusations brought against me by the Jews ;
44026003	" especially since you are an export in all Jewish customs and questions . I pray you , expert in all Jewish customs and questions . I pray you , hear me with patience .
44026004	" The kind of life I have lived from my youth upward among my own nation and at Jerusalem , all that early life of mine , is well known to all the Jews .
44026005	" They know me of old , if they are willing to testify , how that according to the strict sect of our religion , I lived a Pharisee .
44026006	" Today I am standing trial because of the hope of the promise made by God to our ancestors ,
44026007	" a promise which our twelve tribes , earnestly serving God night and day , hope to attain . It is concerning this hope , King Agrippa , that I am accused by the Jews .
44026008	" Why is it deemed incredible by you all , if God raises the dead ?
44026009	" I indeed once thought with myself that I ought to do many things against the name of Jesus , the Nazarene .
44026010	" And this also I did in Jerusalem . Armed with authority from the chief priests , I shut up many of the saints in prison , and when they were condemned to death I gave my vote against them .
44026011	" In all the synagogues also I punished them oftentimes , and tried to make them blaspheme ; and in my mad fury I was pursuing them even to foreign cities .
44026012	" On this errand I was traveling to Damascus one day , armed with authority and commission of the chief priests ,
44026013	" when at noon , as I journeyed , O King , I saw a light from heaven , brighter than the sun , shining around me and around those who journeyed with me .
44026014	" We all fell to the ground ; and I heard a voice saying to me in Hebrew . " Saul , Saul , why are you persecuting me ? It is hard for you to kick against the goad .
44026015	" Who are you , Lord ? I said . " And the Lord said . I am Jesus whom you are persecuting .
44026016	" But rise and stand on your feet , for I have appeared to you in order to appoint you my minister and my witness both of what you have already seen and of those things in which I will appear to you .
44026017	" I will deliver you from the Jewish people , and from the Gentiles to whom I am sending you to open their eyes
44026018	" so that they may turn from darkness to light , and from the power of Satan unto God , in order to receive remission of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in me .
44026019	" So then , O King Agrippa , I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision ;
44026020	" but I proceeded to preach , first to those in Damascus , and then in Jerusalem and throughout all the country of Judea , and also to the Gentiles , that they must repent and turn to God and do deeds worthy of repentance .
44026021	" For this reason the Jews seized me in the temple , and tried to kill me .
44026022	" But having obtained the help that comes from God , I stand even to this day witnessing both to small and great , saying nothing except what the prophets and Moses said should come ;
44026023	" how that the Christ must suffer , and how he should be the first to rise from the dead , and should bring a message of light to the Jewish people and to the Gentiles . "
44026024	As Paul thus made his defense , Festus exclaimed in a loud voice . " Paul , you are raving mad ; your great learning is driving you mad . "
44026025	" I am not mad , most noble Festus , " said Paul ,
44026026	" I am speaking words of sober truth . For the King , to whom I am speaking freely , knows of these matters . I am persuaded that not one of these things has escaped his notice ; for these things were not done in a corner .
44026027	" King Agrippa , do you believe the prophets ? I know that you believe . "
44026028	Agrippa answered , " In short , you are doing your best to persuade me to become a Christian . "
44026029	" Long or short , " answered Paul , " my prayer to God is that not only you but all who are my hearers this day might become such as I am , save for these chains . "
44026030	Then the king rose , and Bernice , and those who were sitting with him .
44026031	When they had withdrawn they continued talking to one another . " This man is doing nothing , " they said , " for which he deserves death or imprisonment . "
44026032	And Agrippa said to Festus , " If he had not appealed to Caesar , he might have been set free . "
44027001	When it was decided that we should sail for Italy , they proceeded to hand over Paul and a few other prisoners to the custody of Julius , a centurion of the Imperial Regiment .
44027002	We embarked in a ship of Adramyttium which was about to sail to the ports of the province of Asia , and put to sea . Aristarchus , a Macedonian of Thessalonica , accompanied us .
44027003	The next day we touched at Sidon . There Julius treated Paul kindly , and gave him leave to visit his friends and refresh himself .
44027004	Putting to sea from thence we sailed under the lee of Cyprus , because the winds were against us ;
44027005	and after sailing across the Cilician and Pamphylian waters , we came to Myra , in Lycia .
44027006	And there the centurion found an Alexandrian ship bound for Italy , and put us on board of her .
44027007	For many days we sailed slowly , and then arrived with difficulty over against Cnidus ; from this point , as the wind did not further favor us , we ran under the lee of Crete , off Cape Salmone ;
44027008	and coasting along with difficulty we reached a place called Fair Havens , not far from the town of Lasea .
44027009	By this time the season was far advanced , and sailing had become dangerous ( for the Autumn Fast was past ) ; so Paul began to warn them .
44027010	" Sirs , " he said to them , " I perceive that the voyage will be attended with injury and serious loss , not only to the cargo and to the ship , but also to our own lives . "
44027011	But the centurion paid greater heed to the master and to the owner than to anything that was spoken by Paul ;
44027012	and as the harbor was ill adapted for winter quarters , the majority advised putting out to sea from thence , to see whether they could get to Phoenix and winter there , a harbor on the coast of Crete facing northeast and southeast .
44027013	And when the south wind blew softly , supposing that they had obtained their purpose , they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete , close in shore .
44027014	But it was not long before a furious wind , called Euroclydon , rushed down from the island ;
44027015	when the ship was caught and could not face the wind , we gave way to it , and let her drive .
44027016	Then we ran under the lee of a little island named Claudia , where with great difficulty we were able to secure the ships boat .
44027017	After hauling it aboard , they used ropes to undergird the ship , and since they were fearful lest they should be driven upon the Syrtes , they lowered the gear and lay to .
44027018	And as we were being terribly battered by the storm , the next day they began to throw the freight overboard ,
44027019	and on the third day with their own hands they threw the ships tackling overboard .
44027020	Then when for many days neither sun nor stars were seen , and a great tempest still beat upon us , all hope that we should be saved was now taken away from us .
44027021	When for a long time they had been without food , Paul stood among them and said . " Men , you ought to have listened to me , and not have set sail from Crete , and so have spared yourselves this injury and loss .
44027022	" But now take courage . There will be no loss of life among you , but only of the ship ,
44027023	" for last night an angel of the God whose I am and whom I serve , stood by me and said .
44027024	" Fear not , Paul ; you must stand before Caesar . Behold , God has granted you the lives of all who are sailing with you .
44027025	" So take courage , men ! I believe God , I believe that things will turn out exactly as it has been told me .
44027026	" But we must be cast upon a certain island . "
44027027	It was now the fourteenth night , and we were drifting through the Adriatic Sea when , about midnight , the sailors began to suspect that they were drawing near to some land .
44027028	So they sounded and found twenty fathoms ; and after a little they sounded again , and found fifteen fathoms .
44027029	Then , fearing lest we should run ashore on the rocks , they threw out four anchors from the stern , and longed for day to come .
44027030	And when the sailors were trying to flee from the ship , and had lowered the boat into the sea under pretext of laying anchors from the bow ,
44027031	Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers , " Unless these men remain on the ship , you cannot be saved . "
44027032	Then the soldiers cut the ropes of the ships boat and let her fall off .
44027033	And while day was dawning , Paul kept urging them all to take some food . " This is the fourteenth day , " he said , " that you have been on the watch , fasting , having eaten nothing .
44027034	" So I beg you to take some food , for this is for your safety . For there shall not a hair perish from the head of any one of you . "
44027035	When he had so said and had taken bread , he gave thanks to God before them all , and broke it and began to eat .
44027036	Then they all cheered up and themselves took food .
44027037	There were in the ship two hundred and seventy-six souls , all told .
44027038	After eating a hearty meal , they began to lighten the ship by throwing the wheat overboard .
44027039	When it was day they tried in vain to recognize the land , but they spied an inlet with a sandy beach , and they began conferring to see whether they could drive the ship into it .
44027040	They cast off the anchors and left them in the sea , and unloosing at the same time the ropes that tied the rudders , they hoisted the foresail to the breeze , and headed for the beach .
44027041	But coming to a place where two seas met , they ran the ship aground ; the bow struck and remained fixed , but the stern began to break up under the violence of the waves .
44027042	Now the soldiers were planning to kill the prisoners , lest any of them should swim off and so escape .
44027043	But the centurion kept them from their purpose , because he wished to save Paul . He gave orders that those who could swim should first jump overboard and get to land ;
44027044	and that the rest should follow , some on planks and some on other bits of wreckage . And so it came to pass that all escaped safe to the land .
44028001	And when we were escaped , we ascertained that the island was called Malta .
44028002	The foreign-speaking people showed us uncommon kindness , for they lighted a fire and made us all welcome , because of the rain and because of the cold .
44028003	Now when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and thrown them on the fire , a viper crawled out because of the heat , and fastened on his hand .
44028004	When the natives saw the reptile hanging on his hand , they began saying to one another , " No doubt this man is a murderer , whom , though he has escaped from the sea , yet justice does not allow him to live . "
44028005	However , he shook off the reptile into the fire and received no harm .
44028006	But they kept expecting him to swell up or fall down dead suddenly . But after waiting a long time , and seeing no harm come to him , they changed their minds , and said over and over that he was a god .
44028007	Now in the neighborhood there were estates belonging to the governor of the island , whose name was Publius . He received us and entertained us for three days courteously .
44028008	It happened however that the father of Publius was lying ill of fever and dysentery . So Paul went to see him and prayed and laid his hands on him and healed him .
44028009	After this all the other sick people on the island came , and continued to be restored to health .
44028010	These loaded us with many honors and , when at last we set sail , they put on board such things as we needed .
44028011	Three months passed before we set sail an Alexandrian ship which had wintered in the island . Its name was " The Twin Brothers . "
44028012	And touching at Syracuse , we stayed there three days .
44028013	From thence , tacking round , we reached Rhegium . Next day a south wind sprang up , which brought us in a day to Puteoli .
44028014	There we found brothers who invited us to stay a week with them . Then we reached Rome .
44028015	From there the brothers , when they heard about us , came out to meet us as far as the Appian Forum and the Three Taverns . When Paul saw them he thanked God and took courage .
44028016	When we finally entered Rome , Paul was allowed to live by himself with the soldier to guard him .
44028017	Now three days later he called the leading Jews together , and when they were come together he said to them . " Brothers , I was delivered a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans , though I had done nothing against the people or the customs of your fathers .
44028018	" Then when they had examined me they wanted to set me at liberty because there was no cause of death in me .
44028019	" But when the Jews objected I was forced to appeal to Caesar , not that I had anything to accuse my nation of .
44028020	This is the reason why I begged you to see and speak with me . For because of the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain . "
44028021	They said to him . " We neither received any letters about you from Judea nor has any brother come hither to report or speak any harm of you .
44028022	" But we are eager to hear from you what it is that you believe ; for we all know that as for this sect it is everywhere spoken against . "
44028023	So they arranged a day with him and came to him in his lodgings in great numbers . He expounded the matter to them ; testifying to the Kingdom of God , and persuading them about Jesus , from morning till evening , both from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets .
44028024	Some began to believe what he said , but some were unbelieving .
44028025	Unable to agree among themselves , they began to go , but not before Paul had spoken a word to them , saying . " Right well did the Holy Spirit say to your ancestors , through the prophet Isaiah .
44028026	" Go to the people and tell them , You will hear and hear , and by no means understand ; And will look , and by no means see .
44028027	For this peoples heart is grown obtuse , Their ears are heavy of hearing , Their eyes have they closed , Lest they should see with their eyes And hear with their ears , Lest they understand with their heart , And turn again , and heal them .
44028028	" Be fully assured , therefore , that this salvation of God is now sent unto the Gentiles . They will listen to it . "
44028029	When he finished speaking , the Jews departed , and reasoned among themselves .
44028030	After this Paul lived for two whole years in his own rented house , and used to receive all who came to see him .
44028031	He continued to preach the kingdom of God , and to teach about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness , quite unmolested .
45001001	From Paul , a slave of Jesus Christ , called to be an apostle , set apart for a gospel of God ,
45001002	which through his prophets he promised beforetime , in holy writings ;
45001003	this gospel is concerning his Son , Jesus Christ our Lord , who was born of Davids posterity in respect of his bodily nature ,
45001004	but was by his resurrection from the dead instated as Son of God , with power , in respect of his spirit of holiness .
45001005	It is through him , even Jesus Christ our Lord , that I received grace and apostleship to promote obedience to the faith among all the Gentiles , for his names sake ;
45001006	among whom you also are called to be Jesus Christs .
45001007	To all that are in Rome , beloved of God , called to be saints . May God our Father , and the Lord Jesus Christ , bless you , and give you peace .
45001008	First I thank my God , through Jesus Christ , for all of you , because your faith is being proclaimed throughout all the world .
45001009	God is my witness , to whom I render holy service in my spirit in the gospel of his Son , how unceasingly I am ever making mention of you in my prayers ,
45001010	always entreating him that now at length , if such be his will , the way may be made clear for me to come to you .
45001011	For I am longing so to see you , in order to impart to you some spiritual gift , so that you may be established ;
45001012	that is , that I with you may be encouraged by you , each of us by the others faith , yours and mine .
45001013	I want you to know , brothers , that many a time I have planned to come to you - though until now I have been hindered - so as to have some harvest-fruit among you also , even as I have among the rest of the Gentiles .
45001014	To Greeks and to barbarians , to the cultured and to the uncultured , I have a debt to discharge .
45001015	So much as in me is , I am ready to preach the gospel to you also who are in Rome .
45001016	FOR I AM PROUD OF THE GOSPEL . IT IS GODS SAVING POWER FOR EVERY ONE WHO BELIEVES . FOR THE JEW FIRST , AND ALSO FOR THE GENTILE .
45001017	FOR IN IT IS BEING REVEALED A RIGHTEOUSNESS WHICH PROCEEDS FROM GOD , FROM FAITH UNTO FAITH ; AS IT IS WRITTEN .
45001018	For Gods wrath is ever being revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who smother the truth by their unrighteousness .
45001019	This is so because that which may be known of God is manifest among them ; for God has made it manifest to them .
45001020	For ever since the creation of the world his invisible nature , even his everlasting power and divinity , has been clearly seen , being perceived through the things that are made . So they have no excuse .
45001021	For although they knew God , yet they did not glorify him as God , nor give him thanks ; but became vain in their reasoning , and their senseless minds were darkened .
45001022	While they professed to be wise , they became fools ,
45001023	and exchanged the majesty of the imperishable God for an idol , graven in the likeness of perishable man , or of birds and four-footed beasts and creeping things .
45001024	So God gave them up in the lusts of their hearts to impurity , to the dishonoring of their own bodies ;
45001025	because they exchanged the truth of God for an untruth , and worshiped and served the creature , rather than the Creator who is blessed forever . Amen .
45001026	That is why God has given them up to passions of dishonor ; for on the one hand their women actually changed the natural function of sex into that which is against nature ;
45001027	and on the other hand their men likewise abandoned the natural use of women , and were ablaze with passion for one another ; men with men practising shameless acts and receiving in their own person that recompense of their wrong-doing which necessarily followed .
45001028	And just as they refused to continue to retain God in their knowledge , so did God cast them out to an outcast mind , to do those things which were indecent .
45001029	They were overflowing with every kind of iniquity , depravity , greed , and malice . They were full of envy , murder , quarreling , deceit , and malignity .
45001030	They became whisperers , back-biters , hated of God , insolent , haughty , boastful . They invented sins . They were disobedient to parents .
45001031	They were without sense , without faith , without natural affection , without mercy .
45001032	Though they knew well the ordinance of God , that those who practise such vices are worthy of death , they not only continue to do the same , but were even applauding those who practise vice .
45002001	You are therefore inexcusable , O man , whoever you are , that sits in judgment ; for in judging another you are condemning yourself . You , the judge , are habitually practising the very same things .
45002002	" We know that Gods judgment against those who practise such vices is in accord with the truth , " you say ?
45002003	Very well ; and do you suppose , you who judge those that practise such vices , and are doing the very same , that you will elude the judgment of God ?
45002004	Or do you despise the riches of his kindness and forbearance and long patience ? Do you not know that the kindness of God is leading you to repentance ?
45002005	In your hardness and impenitence of heart you are treasuring up for yourself wrath on the Day of Wrath , when the righteous judgment of God is revealed .
45002006	For He will render to every man according to his works ;
45002007	eternal life to those who by patience in well-doing strive for glory and honor and immortality ;
45002008	but anger and wrath upon those who are self-willed and disobey the truth , but obey unrighteousness .
45002009	Anguish and calamity will be upon every soul of man who practises evil , upon the Jew first , and also upon the Gentile ;
45002010	but glory and honor and peace to every man who does good , to the Jew first , and also to the Gentile .
45002011	For there is no partiality with God .
45002012	For all who have sinned without law will also perish without law ; and all who have sinned under law will be judged by law .
45002013	For it is not the hearers of law who are righteous in the eyes of God ; nay , it is the doers of law who will be accounted righteous .
45002014	For when Gentiles , who have no law , obey by natural instinct the commands of the Law , they even though they have no law , are a law to themselves .
45002015	For they show that the work of the Law is written in their hearts , while their conscience bears them witness , as their reasonings accuse , or it may be defend , them ,
45002016	in the day when God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ , according to my gospel .
45002017	Now if you bear the name of a Jew , and rely upon law , and boast yourself in God ,
45002018	and know his will , and can test the things that differ ; if you are instructed out of the Law ,
45002019	and are confident that you yourself are a darkness ,
45002020	an instructor of the foolish , a teacher of the young , because you have in the Law the form of knowledge and of the truth - well then , you who are teaching others , do you ever teach yourself ?
45002021	You who are preaching that a man should not steal , do you practise theft ?
45002022	You who keep saying that a man should not commit adultery , do you commit adultery ? You who hold idols in abhorrence , are you plundering their temples ?
45002023	You who are making your boast in the Law , do you habitually dishonor God through your transgressions of the Law ?
45002024	For the name of God is continually blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you , even as the Scripture itself says .
45002025	Circumcision does indeed profit , if you are obedient to the Law ; but if you habitually break the Law , your circumcision is become uncircumcision .
45002026	So if the uncircumcised keeps the ordinance of the Law , shall not his uncircumcision be reckoned equivalent to circumcision .
45002027	And shall not those who are physically uncircumcised , but who keep the Law , condemn you who are a breaker of the Law , although you have a written law and circumcision ?
45002028	For the real Jew is not the man who is one outwardly , and the real circumcision is not outward in the flesh ;
45002029	but the real Jew is one inwardly , and real circumcision is heart-circumcision , spiritual , not literal , praised not by men , but by God .
45003001	What special privilege , then , has the Jew ? Or what is the use of circumcision ?
45003002	Much in every way . First of all , because to them were entrusted the oracles of God .
45003003	Supposing some of them have proved faithless ?
45003004	By no means ! Be sure that God is ever true , though all mankind prove false . As it is written , That thou mayest be found just in thine argument , And gain thy cause when thou contendest .
45003005	But if our unrighteousness thus brings out Gods righteousness , what shall we say ? Is God unrighteous - I speak after the manner of men - when he inflicts his anger on us ?
45003006	Be it far from us ; for in that case how could God judge the world ?
45003007	But if by a falsehood of mine the truthfulness of God has been made to redound to his glory , why am I still tried as a sinner ?
45003008	And why not say ( as I myself am slanderously reported to say ) , " Let us do evil that good may come out of it " ? Such arguments are rightly condemned .
45003009	What then ? Are we Jews in a better position ? Not at all , for I have already charged all , both Jews and Gentiles , with being under sin .
45003010	As it is written . There is none righteous , no , not one ;
45003011	There is none that understands , none that seeks for God !
45003012	All have swerved from the right path ; Every one of them has become corrupt . There is none that practises good , no , not one .
45003013	Their throat is an open grave ; With their tongues they have used deceit . The venom of asps is under their lips .
45003014	Their mouth is full of cursing and bitterness .
45003015	Their feet are swift to shed blood .
45003016	Destruction and ruin are in their paths ;
45003017	And the path of peace they have not known .
45003018	Reverence for God is not before their eyes .
45003019	Now we know that whatever the Law says , it speaks to those who are under the Law ; so that every mouth may be shut , and all the world may be brought under the judgment of God .
45003020	For no man will be justified in Gods sight by works of the Law ; for through the Law comes the consciousness of sin .
45003021	But now , quite apart from any law , a righteousness coming from God has been fully brought to light , continually witnessed to by the Law and the Prophets .
45003022	I mean a righteousness coming from God through faith in Jesus Christ , for all who believe . For there is no distinction between Jew and Gentile ,
45003023	since all have sinned and lack the glory which comes from God ;
45003024	but they are now being justified by his free grace through the deliverance that is in Christ Jesus .
45003025	For God openly set him forth for himself as an offering of atonement through faith , by means of his blood , in order to show forth his righteousness - since in his forbearance he had passed over the sins previously committed - to show forth his righteousness ,
45003026	I say , at this present time ; that he himself might be just , and yet the justifier of him who has faith in Jesus .
45003027	Then what becomes of boasting ? It is shut out . What sort of law forbids it ? A law of works ? No , but a law of faith .
45003028	For I conclude that a man is justified by faith , altogether apart from the deeds of the Law .
